title: 105_hr3048
content:
The "Digital Era Copyright Enhancement Act" amends fair use laws to include digital transmissions and restricts consideration of how a work is performed or technological measures applied. It also addresses library and archive exemptions. Section 108 of title 17, United States Code is amended to include provisions for copyright notice on reproduced copies or phonorecords. Subsection (b) now requires three copies or phonorecords instead of one, and subsection (c) also requires three copies or phonorecords. Section 108 of title 17, United States Code is amended to include provisions for copyright notice on reproduced copies or phonorecords. The amendment includes requirements for three copies or phonorecords instead of one, and specifies conditions for when the existing format of a work has become obsolete. SEC. 4. FIRST SALE.

Section 109 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to allow the owner of a digital copy to transmit the work to a single recipient as long as the original copy is erased simultaneously. This transmission does not infringe on copyright.

SEC. 5. DISTANCE LEARNING. The title of section 110 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to "Limitations on exclusive rights: Exemption of certain activities". Section 110(2) is amended to allow performance, display, or distribution of a work during analog or digital transmission for systematic instructional activities of governmental bodies or nonprofit educational institutions directly related to teaching content. Section 112(b) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to allow the performance, display, or distribution of works for systematic instructional activities of governmental bodies or nonprofit educational institutions. SEC. 6 amends section 117 of title 17, United States Code, allowing for the making of digital copies of works if it is incidental to lawful use and does not conflict with the author's interests. SEC. 7 addresses preemption. SEC. 7 of title 17, United States Code, addresses preemption by stating that non-negotiable license terms cannot limit the use of uncopyrightable material or restrict exclusive rights. SEC. 8 introduces a new chapter on copyright protection and management systems. Sec. 1201 prohibits the circumvention of technological measures used by copyright owners to prevent reproduction of their work for the purpose of infringement. Conduct such as removing or deactivating these measures is not allowed, except for manufacturing, importing, or distributing devices or computer programs. This section does not apply to conduct governed by a separate chapter of the title. Sec. 1202 defines effective technological measures as changes in digital data to protect copyright owner rights. It includes encryption, scrambling, or attributes that cannot be removed without degrading the work. It also prohibits knowingly providing false copyright management information. Sec. 1202 prohibits knowingly providing false copyright management information, including distributing or importing altered information without authority. The term 'copyright management information' refers to electronic information identifying a work, including author and copyright owner details, and it is illegal to remove or alter this information without authority. The term 'copyright management information' includes details such as the copyright owner, terms of use, identifying numbers, and other prescribed information. It does not include personally identifiable information of the user. Civil remedies are available for violations of this information. Civil remedies are available for violations of copyright management information, allowing aggrieved persons to bring civil actions in court for injunctions, equitable relief, damages, costs recovery, and attorney's fees. The court may award actual damages or statutory damages for violations of copyright management information, with statutory damages ranging from $250 to $2,500 per violation. The court may award statutory damages for violations of copyright management information, ranging from $250 to $2,500 per violation. Additionally, for repeated violations within three years, the court may increase the damages to double the original amount. The court may award damages up to double the amount for copyright management information violations. In cases of innocent violation, the court can reduce or eliminate the damages if the violator proves they were unaware of the violation. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends the table of sections and chapters in title 17, United States Code. Revises items related to limitations on exclusive rights. Adds a new chapter on Copyright Protection and Management Systems. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATES. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATES. Sections one through seven and section 9(a) of this Act will take effect upon enactment. Section 8 and section 9(b) will take effect when the WIPO Copyright Treaty and WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty are in force in the US.
